abstract.p: Los Angeles Craft and Folk Art Museum opens an exhibition of handicrafts from Slovenia; photo (S)

block.p: The Los Angeles Craft and Folk Art Museum has opened an exhibition of handicrafts from Slovenia, which broke away from Yugoslavia in 1991. Rok Kvaternik, an entrepreneurial publisher based in Ljubljana, selected works by 100 top artisans. Some are based on continuing Slovenian traditions like egg dying, while others reinterpret traditional handicrafts in stone and wood, ceramics, fibers and leathers. At far left is a dress made of layered corn husks (traditionally woven) by Stanislava Vauda ($870). Janez Golob's wooden bowls are hand-turned. The exhibition runs through Sept. 3; 5814 Wilshire Boulevard, (323) 937-4230. Some of the crafts can be ordered from the museum store, (323) 857-4677. A painted Easter egg is $7, a hand-turned wooden bowl $90.
